oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: T. Graham Brown Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with T. Graham Brown (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: T. Graham Brown; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) T. Graham Brown talks about his family and his son Anthony (Acme) Brown -- (00:27) Brown talks about his birth and moving around Georgia as his father worked as a salesman -- (01:09) Brown talks about his father's decision to work at the University of Georgia and transferring from high school straight to the University of Georgia -- (01:49) Brown talks about being an honorary member of the fraternities because of his performances -- (02:35) Brown talks about Danny Brown being a president of Lambda Chi Alpha and -- (03:17) Brown tells of how he believed baseball would be his eventual profession -- (03:40) Brown recalls choosing to work at the Holiday Inn as a performer over being on the bench of the baseball team -- (04:54) Brown talks about his David Allan Coe phase in 1975 at the age of twenty-one -- (06:00) Brown talks about his transition to a country rocker -- (06:58) Brown tells of how he changed his direction when creating T. Graham Brown Can of Spam -- (08:00) Brown tells how in 1982 a friend had decided to tell Brown to leave Athens, Georgia -- (09:19) Brown and Biff Collie talk about how Brown had never graduated college -- (10:32) Brown talks about his aunt Golden Brown and creating T. for his artist name -- (11:19) Brown tells of how he chose Nashville over a larger city -- (12:15) Brown tells of how he met his wife, Sheila Brown, and her drive -- (14:08) Sheila Brown's master degree is discussed by Brown to have happened at the perfect time to move -- (15:00) Brown talks about Sheila working for two jobs to support Brown's dream -- (15:51) Brown talks about taking his 59' Ford Wagon to Nashville to live -- (16:30) Brown tells about how he blew through his money and how he went around discovering his social connections -- (17:40) Brown tells of recording with CBS Songs and working for Screen Gems EMI -- (18:15) Collie and Brown talk about the cocky producer who gave him his first break -- (20:03) Brown tells of his contract signed on a napkin and the other contract options -- (20:43) Brown and Collie discuss commercial sales and Brown being brought up with a feeling of guilt -- (22:58) Brown discusses a time where David Briggs got him a commercial spot with Coca-Cola -- (24:17) Collie and Brown talk about the various revenues made from commercials -- (26:00) Brown tells of how he had to move back to his father's farm while working on his music career -- (26:57) Brown tells of how he has calmed himself as a performer to become a country music star -- (28:40) Brown tells the story of how he gave up drinking -- (29:04) Collie recalls an article on Brown and Brown reflects on a story about Andy Griffith and a septic tank -- (30:15) Brown tells of being in Toronto at the Maple Leaf Garden and doing an interview in Georgia -- (31:38) Collie and Brown discuss Griffith's influence on Brown -- (32:21) Brown tells a story of Kenny Rogers sending his son a gift and reflects on Rogers influence from giving Brown a chance -- (35:54) Brown tells of his attempts to out-do Rogers -- (36:54) Brown talks about a liquor shop owner "Bubber" that would cash peoples checks who was murdered by his wife -- (38:53) Brown recalls "Bubber" being the hub on news and someone owing him -- (40:55) Collie and Brown discuss fishing in middle Tennessee -- (41:32) Collie starts a word game featuring: Brown's parent's zip code, Brown's eighth grade teacher, Lovable pudding head, Brown's first job, Brown being called the Huey Lewis, Kenny Rogers, Brown's experience at Georgia, Brown's idea of George Jones, Brown's respect for Otis Redding, Brown being a "Hip-Hick," and Brown's tattoo of a heart with a star -- (44:06) Collie and Brown talk about the possibility of Brown being a preacher
